awd_titl_txt: Enhancing Computational Capabilities of the TeraGrid
awd_abstract_narration: The University of Texas at Austin will deploy and support a powerful HPC system that will provide support for a broad range of scientific applications. The system is a 302 TF Dell cluster with 44 TB memory and 1.2 PB disk. This balanced system has 5x the peak performance, and will also deliver 2x the ?real? performance per-core on science applications through much greater memory and interconnect bandwidth than the current system. It also offers 4x the total memory and 10x the disk capacity, with a scalable path to adding more computational and storage capacity.  The system will provide 75 million hours of computer time to the current TeraGrid allocation process and an additional minimum of 15 million hours through the TACC allocation process.  Thus approximately 50% of the system will go to NSF peer reviewed scientific research.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The Lonestar supercomputer project at the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) at the University of Texas at Austin provided a highly reliable and efficient high performance computing resource that became the workhorse for thousands of researchers in hundreds of projects. The Lonestar system was partially funded by NSF ($2.86M) and with other funding sources totaling $11.4M, providing a 311 TeraFlops (TF) system. This leveraged funding approach enabled researchers to perform larger-scale runs, and while NSF provided roughly 25% of the funding, XSEDE-allocated researchers consumed nearly 40% of the compute cycles. With 2-4x greater application performance than the previously deployed NSF Track 2 system Ranger that was also at TACC, Lonestar was in high demand over the entire 3.5-year life of the project. Deployed in April of 2011, Lonestar debuted at #28 on the Top500 list, with 22,656 Intel Westmere processor cores and a peak performance of 302 TF.

 

The individual scientific impacts of Lonestar across a wide range of science domains are too numerous to mention, but we would in particular like to highlight the impacts of Lonestar in support of the Life Sciences. Among many other Life Science outcomes, Lonestar was used to find a link between Alzheimer’s and cancer via a shared pathway in gene transcription, to more expediently sequence plant and animal genomes to meet the growing world-demand for food, to determine anticancer drugs through the study of H-Ras proteins, and for enabling researchers to share and analyze fMRI brain scans in furtherance of understanding the complexities of how the brain functions. All of these examples show the impact NSF’s high performance computing is having on our health and quality of life.

 

By all objective measures, the Lonestar project was a tremendous success. The demand for access by researchers far outweighed the available time on the system at every quarterly XSEDE allocation meeting. By the end of its lifetime, Lonestar rivaled Ranger’s outcomes, having delivered nearly two million successful jobs to the user community, on more than 1,200 projects to more than 3,500 users across more than 100 disciplines of engineering and science. Operationally, Lonestar significantly exceeded the uptime target of 95%, coming in at 98% over the life of the project.

 

In addition to the system itself, TACC staff provided user support, training, system administration, and network administration to ensure continuous availability and proper utilization of these resources. TACC provided 24x7 on-site coverage and more than a dozen staff members worked on the Lonestar project. Training, education, and outreach activities mainly leveraged the XSEDE project, although Lonestar-specific webcasts to provide new user information drew excellent attendance.

 

The outcomes described herein show that Lonestar was an extremely successful and highly impactful computing system funded by the National Science Foundation, and an exemplar of the ongoing need for high performance computing across the vast fields of science.

Modified by: Tommy K Minyard
